courseTitle: MATLAB Programming for Kinesiology and Rehabilitation
courseDescription: Developments in technology provide researchers with the ability to measure different aspects of human movement many times a second. To make sense of these large and complex datasets researchers are increasingly using engineering software, e.g., MATLAB, to manipulate, process, and analyze data. In this course, students will gain experience importing, plotting, filtering, selecting critical points, and exporting data through the creation of custom functions and scripts within the MATLAB user interface.

courseTitle: Mixed and Multi Methods in Health Sciences Research
courseDescription: This course will cover the writing and refining of research questions, collecting and analyzing qualitative and quantitative data, and choosing the appropriate mixed or multi-method design. The course will also review analyzing, interpreting, and presenting the results of a mixed or multi method design to address the research questions. Students will learn how qualitative and quantitative data can be combined to capture the perspectives of healthcare providers, patients, organizations, or other stakeholders to answer research questions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Collecting and analyzing qualitative and quantitative data
Choosing appropriate mixed or multi-method design
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing research questions with mixed or multi-method design
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and analyzing data from multiple sources

courseTitle: Theoretical Models in Kinesiology and Rehabilitation
courseDescription: This course will explore some of the theories that are common to kinesiology and rehabilitation research. It will include theories associated with disablement, rehabilitation, patient-centered care, motor control, and models for clinical research. These theories will be applied to clinical and research applications relevant to kinesiology and rehabilitation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of disablement and rehabilitation theories
Applying clinical research models in kinesiology and rehabilitation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying theories to solve rehabilitation challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and interpreting clinical research results

courseTitle: Critical Appraisal and Synthesis of Evidence in Kinesiology and Rehabilitation
courseDescription: This course will introduce the student to critical appraisal of all forms of research in kinesiology and rehabilitation. The purpose of this course is to further develop the student's competence in conducting and evaluating research. The student will develop the skills necessary to find, critically evaluate, and synthesize the available research in order to answer individual research questions or cultivate a line of research inquiry.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research methodology in kinesiology and rehabilitation
Appraisal of kinesiology and rehabilitation research
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of kinesiology and rehabilitation research

courseDescription: This course examines the coordination of cardiorespiratory, musculoskeletal, and neurological systems in performing rhythmic movement tasks such as walking, running, swallowing, speaking, and feeding. Students will gain experience measuring and interpreting cardiorespiratory variables, kinematics, kinetics, and energetics of rhythmic movement tasks integrated with measures of activity, participation, and clinical standardized tests.
Technical and Digital Skills: Assessing energetics of rhythmic movement tasks
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting findings on rhythmic movement tasks
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting results from kinematics, kinetics, and energetics measures
Applying clinical standardized tests in practical scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing data from various physical systems
Leading discussions on rhythmic movement tasks

courseDescription: This course will examine the coordination of musculoskeletal and neurological systems in performing discrete movement tasks such as reaching, grasping, throwing and speaking. Students will gain experience measuring and interpreting kinematics and kinetics of discrete tasks integrated with measures of activity and participation and clinical standardized tests.
Technical and Digital Skills: Measuring kinematics and kinetics of discrete tasks
Interpreting measured data of discrete tasks
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating musculoskeletal and neurological system studies

courseDescription: This course covers neuroscience with specific regard to the fundamental design, organization and workings of the central nervous system (CNS) in the areas of motor control. The topics cover areas related to the typical development of motor function and changes in motor control throughout the lifespan. This course also assesses motor-control problems that occur as a result of congenital conditions, acquired damage, dysfunction or disease. Pathological conditions such as (but not limited to) stroke, Parkinson's disease, cerebellar disease, and muscle and joint pathologies are examined.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of the central nervous system (CNS)
Knowledge of the typical development of motor function
Understanding of pathological conditions such as stroke, Parkinson's disease, cerebellar disease, and muscle and joint pathologies
Assessment of motor-control problems due to congenital conditions, acquired damage, dysfunction or disease
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining the changes in motor control throughout the lifespan
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing changes in motor control throughout the lifespan
Understanding and interpreting the impact of pathological conditions on motor control

courseDescription: An optimal level of balance and postural control is essential for the performance of many everyday activities. This course is specifically focused on the neural, muscular and biomechanical mechanisms underlying postural control in healthy populations of different ages. In addition, changes that can be observed in postural control following damage, dysfunction and/or disease are also covered. The implications of changes in balance control for falls will be a particular focus. Students in this course learn how to collect and interpret kinematic, kinetic and electrophysiological data associated with the neuromuscular function during posture and balance tasks.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of neural, muscular, and biomechanical mechanisms
Interpretation of kinematic, kinetic and electrophysiological data
Knowledge of neuromuscular function during posture and balance tasks
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of postural control in different age groups
Understanding and interpretation of changes in postural control due to damage, dysfunction, or disease
Identification and understanding of implications of balance control changes for falls

courseDescription: Rehabilitation aims to enhance the functional ability of individuals with impairment or disease, while areas within the field of kinesiology seek to understand changes in tissues, physiological systems, movements, and behaviors that occur through training and practice. In this course, students will study these related processes of adaptation, learning, and rehabilitation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Study and analysis of physiological systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Diagnosis and analysis of physical impairments
Adaptation and modification of rehabilitation techniques

courseTitle: Structured Teaching Experience for Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Professions
courseDescription: This course is designed to provide supervised and mentored teaching experience within fields applicable to kinesiology and rehabilitation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of kinesiology and rehabilitation principles
Application of teaching methodologies within the field
Usage of rehabilitation and physical therapy equipment
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of concepts and principles
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adaptation of teaching methods based on individual learning needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organizational skills for teaching sessions

courseTitle: Special Topics in Kinesiology and Rehabilitation
courseDescription: The advanced study of special topics in kinesiology and rehabilitation.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting physical therapies based on individual needs

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide supervised and mentored research experience within specialized topics applicable to kinesiology and rehabilitation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data collection in kinesiology and rehabilitation
Data analysis in kinesiology and rehabilitation

courseDescription: An approved research project written under the supervision of a faculty advisor, in which the student demonstrates the capacity to design and complete independent applied research. The completed project must be approved by the dissertation committee.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with faculty advisor and dissertation committee
